questions.text: Match the correct antidote with the given drug toxicity: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzodiazepine: Flumazenil

 

Explanation: 


Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Mechanism - it acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor site on the GABA-A receptor complex. By competitively blocking these receptors, it can rapidly reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation and respiratory depression.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Atropine: L-carnitine: Incorrect. Physostigmine is the antidote for atropine poisoning as it can reverse both peripheral and central anticholinergic effects. L-carnitine is used specifically for valproate-induced hepatotoxicity.

 

Option B. Barbiturate: Fomepizole: Incorrect. Barbiturates do not have a specific antidote - management involves alkalinization of urine to enhance excretion. Fomepizole is the antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning as it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Desferrioxamine: Incorrect. British Anti-Lewisite (BAL/Dimercaprol) is the antidote for arsenic poisoning. Desferrioxamine is specifically used for iron poisoning (both acute poisoning and chronic overload).

 

Educational Objective: 


Antidotes

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic drug. It also produces sedation and adverse effects like dry mouth and hypotension. All these actions result due to action on which of the following receptors?(INICET MAY 2024)

 

1. D2 and 5HT2 receptors

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic receptors

3. Muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic receptors

4. H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Chlorpromazine is a typical anti-psychotic drug having main mechanism of antipsychotic action as D2 blockade and minor as 5 HT2 blockade. However, it also blocks many other receptors that can result in adverse effects.

 

While chlorpromazine does block H1 receptors causing sedation, it is not the sole receptor responsible for its adverse effects. It must be considered in conjunction with D2, 5HT2, muscarinic, and alpha-adrenergic receptors.

 

Other Option:

 

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic Receptors: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of anti-psychotic drugs

 

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/470-471

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of infective valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. Histologic finding shows an aggregate of fungal hypae with acute angle branching and rare fruiting body (GMS stain) suggestive of aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus – septate, acute branching (40 degrees), and form fruiting bodies. Aspergillus hyphae with the distinct fruiting body can be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor - The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°.

 

 

Option B. Fusarium - Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. It cannot be distinguished from aspergillus by morphology alone and requires culture for identification.

 

Option C. Rhizopus - The main difference between Mucor and Rhizopus is that the Mucor does not have rhizoids and stolons while Rhizopus has both rhizoids and stolons. Further, Mucor has branched sporangiophore while the sporangiophore of Rhizopus is generally unbranched. Also, the Mucor does not have apophyses whereas, the Rhizopus has apophyses in the sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

Rotavirus is among the most common identifiable viral causes of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years. Most cases are asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance.

 

Diagnosis – ELISA – Detects rotavirus antigen in Stool

 

  • Molecular methods – PCR, BioFilm Array

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antigen detection in blood: Not used for rotavirus as the virus does not typically present in blood.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: This method is not typically used for acute diagnosis as it indicates past exposure rather than current infection.

 

Option D. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is ineffective for viruses like rotavirus due to their small size and lack of distinctive morphology in light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigen detection in stool samples is the standard diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection, crucial for implementing appropriate management strategies, especially in managing dehydration risks in young children.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukoplakia

 

  • Leukoplakia is characterized by the presence of white patches on the oral mucosa, which cannot be scraped off.
  • The patches may vary in appearance, from smooth to rough or nodular.
  • Common risk factors include tobacco use (both smoking and smokeless forms) and chronic alcohol consumption.
  • While it's a benign lesion, there is a risk of malignant transformation, which is why regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas are vital.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia: Erythroplakia is less common than leukoplakia but has a higher potential for being either cancerous at the time of diagnosis or becoming malignant later. It appears as red patches or plaques and is often more concerning due to its higher risk of malignancy.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, progressive scarring disease, mostly linked to areca nut (betel nut) chewing. It's particularly prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. It's characterized by stiffness of the oral mucosa leading to trismus (difficulty in opening the mouth), burning sensation on eating spicy food, and oral ulcers. Over time, the condition can progress, making it hard for the patient to open their mouth. This condition also has a risk of malignant transformation, and like leukoplakia, requires regular monitoring.

 

Option D. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs, including the bladder, kidneys, and even the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of the oral cavity, it's extremely rare. It presents as soft yellow plaques. Histologically, it's characterized by the presence of unique cells called "Michaelis-Gutmann bodies".

 

  • Given the presentation described - white patches on the tongue and inner cheek of a chronic alcohol abuser - the diagnosis of leukoplakia (option A) is the most probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukoplakia is an oral mucosal lesion characterized by white patches that cannot be scraped off and is commonly associated with tobacco and alcohol use.
  • It has the potential for malignant transformation, necessitating regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas.

questions.text: What is the odor of a mummified body? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Odorless

 

A mummified body is characterized by the absence of moisture, leading to its preservation. This process results in the body becoming dry and leathery, which eliminates the conditions necessary for the growth of bacteria responsible for producing foul odors.

 

Mummification:

 

  • Odor: Mummified bodies are odorless due to the absence of moisture, which inhibits bacterial growth and decomposition.
  • Appearance: The body becomes dry and leathery, preserving it in a desiccated state.

 

Comparison with Other Types of Decomposition:

 

  • Adipocere Formation:
    • Odor: An adipocere body has a foul, rancid smell similar to decomposing fats.
    • Formation: Adipocere, also known as "grave wax," forms when body fat undergoes a chemical transformation into a waxy substance, typically in moist environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pungent: This odor is might be present in cases of certain chemical exposures or other types of decomposition.

 

Option C. Putrid: This odor is characteristic of bodies undergoing typical decomposition, where bacterial activity produces foul-smelling gases.

 

Option D. Offensive: Similar to putrid, this term describes the unpleasant odors produced during the normal decomposition process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mummified body is odorless due to its dry and preserved state, an adipocere body which has foul rancid smell (like decomposing fats)

questions.text: Death sentence can be given by: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A. Session court judge and B. Additional session court

 

Explanation:

 

In the Indian judicial system, both the Session Court and the Additional Session Court have the authority to pass a death sentence. However, any death sentence given by these courts must be confirmed by the High Court before it can be carried out. The Supreme Court and High Court can also issue death sentences directly.

 

It is important to note that the Assistant Sessions Court Judge and the Additional Sessions Court Judge are not the same. An Assistant Sessions Court Judge is a junior position and does not have the power to issue a death sentence.

 

Other Option:

 

Option. C. Chief judicial magistrate: The Chief Judicial Magistrate does not have the authority to pass a death sentence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, death sentences can be issued by the Session Court, Additional Session Court, High Court, and Supreme Court. However, any death sentence passed by the Session Court or Additional Session Court must be confirmed by the High Court before it can be executed.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the X-ray? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patella fracture

 

The X-ray provided shows a clear fracture line through the patella, indicating a patella fracture.

 

In the provided image, the presence of a sharp, discontinuous line through the patella confirms the diagnosis of a patella fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemarthrosis: This condition would cause swelling in the joint but would not show a fracture line. The X-ray does not indicate swelling without a fracture, ruling out hemarthrosis.

 

 

Option C. Bipartite patella: This is a congenital condition where the patella is naturally in two parts. It shows smooth, well-defined borders unlike the jagged edges seen in fractures. The X-ray here clearly shows a fracture line, not a bipartite patella.

 

 

Option D. Ligament injury: Ligament injuries do not show up on X-rays as they involve soft tissues. Thus, this option is not relevant to the findings on the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patella fracture can be identified on an X-ray by a distinct fracture line through the patella, differentiating it from other conditions like hemarthrosis, bipartite patella, and ligament injuries.

questions.text: 52-year-old man collapses and you are giving CPR with your friend. What is the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult life support, the standard ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers. This ratio ensures that there is an adequate number of compressions to maintain circulation, while also providing necessary breaths to maintain oxygenation

 

In pediatric Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS), the ratio can vary depending on the number of rescuers. If there is only one rescuer, the ratio remains 30:2. However, if there are two rescuers, the ratio can change to 15:2.

For neonates, the ratio is different, typically 3:1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adult CPR, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is always 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers.

questions.text:
Which diagnostic investigation is utilized to identify the condition characterized by a 40-year-old man displaying abrupt erythematous painful lesions on the trunk and face, joint pain, and glove and stock anesthesia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Nerve examination
  2. Skin biopsy
  3. Slit skin smear
  4. Mantoux test
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy. The diagnosis of this condition requires nerve examination, skin biopsy, and a slit skin smear (option B - 1, 2, 3).

 

The clinical presentation described suggests a condition called leprosy or Hansen's disease, which can cause skin lesions, nerve damage resulting in anaesthesia, and joint pain.

 

1. Nerve examination: An essential part of the diagnosis of leprosy involves the examination of nerves for enlargement and tenderness, which can indicate nerve damage due to the disease.

 

2. Skin biopsy: A biopsy of the affected skin can be taken and histologically examined for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

3. Slit skin smear:  This test involves taking a sample from the skin (usually from the earlobes or from lesions) and staining it for acid-fast bacilli, which is a characteristic of Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Mantoux test:

 

  • The Mantoux test is used to diagnose tuberculosis, not leprosy.
  • It involves the tuberculin skin test (TST) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium leprae are both acid-fast bacilli.
  • The Mantoux test is specific for TB and does not directly aid in the diagnosis of leprosy

 

Characteristic clinical features of Hansen’s disease / Leprosy

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae is the cause of the chronic granulomatous disease known as leprosy.
  • The typical incubation period for leprosy is 2 to 12 years.
  • It frequently manifests as a visible skin lesion, such as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule, or as a numb spot on the skin.
  • The face, buttocks, trunk, and extensor aspects of the limbs are frequently affected by lesions.
  • Skin, cutaneous, and peripheral nerves, as well as mucous membranes, are all impacted.
  • The posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves, are the peripheral nerves that are most frequently affected.
  • The facial nerve is the cranial nerve that is involved most frequently.
  • Both nerve function and hair growth are compromised by the lesions.
  • Burns or ulcers on the amputation limb may also be present in the patients.

 

Additional Information

 

Classification systems of leprosy:

 

Ridley-Jopling classification

 

  • Tuberculoid (TT)
  • Borderline tubercular (BT)
  • Borderline (BB)
  • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
  • Lepromatous (LL)

 

WHO classification:

 

  • Paucibacillary
  • Multibacillary

 

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

 

 

  • The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.
  • Mantoux test is not useful in diagnosis of leprosy. This is the test which helps to explain the prognosis of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic investigations for a suspected case of leprosy include nerve examination, skin biopsy, and slit skin smear to detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae and to assess the extent of nerve damage.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 28 page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants causes the least sexual dysfunction? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mirtazapine

 

The typical antidepressants (SSRI, SNRI, MAO inhibitors and TCA) are notorious for causing sexual disturbances like erectile dysfunction due to increased levels of serotonin. On the other hand, atypical anti-depressants (like mirtazapine and bupropion etc) have lesser propensity to cause these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Fluoxetine: As a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), fluoxetine is commonly associated with sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido, difficulty achieving orgasm, and erectile dysfunction.

 

Options B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). While perhaps slightly less likely to cause sexual side effects than SSRIs, venlafaxine can still lead to sexual

dysfunction in a significant number of patients.

 

Options D. Imipramine: A tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), imipramine can cause sexual dysfunction, often due to its anticholinergic effects. TCAs, in general, are more likely to cause a variety of side effects, including those affecting sexual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant. Apart from increasing the levels of serotonin and nor-adrenaline (due to blockade of presynaptic alpha 2 receptors), It also acts as an antagonist of serotonin (5-HT2 and 5-HT3) receptors. It has some degree of H1 blocking property also. It is therefore known as NSSA (Nor adrenergic and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressant). Mirtazapine is generally associated with a lower incidence of sexual side effects compared to SSRIs and SNRIs, making it a better option for patients concerned about these issues.

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

choices.text: Occurs due to saponification of fats

questions.text: Which of these statements is true for Adipocere change after death? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occurs due to saponification of fats

 

Adipocere formation, also known as saponification, is a postmortem change characterized by the conversion of body fat into a waxy substance called adipocere. This process occurs due to the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of body fats, often in the presence of moisture and certain enzymes. Adipocere is most commonly formed in warm, moist, and anaerobic conditions, but not in extremely high temperatures or cold temperatures.

 

The formation of adipocere is an enzymatic process where body fats are broken down into fatty acids, which then combine with calcium ions to form soap-like compounds. This saponification process helps preserve the body tissues, preventing further decay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs in very high temperature: This option is incorrect because adipocere formation does not require very high temperatures. High temperatures favor mummification by accelerating dehydration rather than promoting saponification.

 

Option B. Occurs in cold temperature: Adipocere formation is less likely in cold conditions, as the enzymatic processes required for saponification are slowed down in low temperatures.

 

Option C. Occurs immediately after death: This is incorrect because adipocere formation takes time and does not occur immediately after death. The process can take weeks to months depending on environmental conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adipocere formation after death occurs due to the saponification of fats through an enzymatic process, primarily under warm, moist, and anaerobic conditions.

questions.text: 40-year-old male was started on tuberculosis treatment after which he started complaining of visual disturbances. Which drug is likely to cause this side effect? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is a first-line antituberculosis medication that is known to cause visual disturbances as a side effect. The most common visual side effect of ethambutol is optic neuritis, which can present with symptoms such as decreased visual acuity, color blindness, and visual field defects. These symptoms are due to the toxic effects of ethambutol on the optic nerve. It is important for patients on ethambutol to have regular ophthalmologic examinations to monitor for early signs of optic neuritis, which can be reversible if the drug is discontinued promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: While isoniazid can cause peripheral neuropathy and, less commonly, optic neuritis, it is not the most common cause of visual disturbances among the antituberculosis drugs.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is known for causing a red-orange discoloration of bodily fluids and potential hepatotoxicity, but it is not commonly associated with visual disturbances.

 

Option C. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is associated with hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia leading to gout, but it is not known to cause visual disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the antituberculosis drug most commonly associated with visual disturbances, particularly optic neuritis.

questions.text: An individual is in an environment of a temperature of 47°C. What is the mechanism of heat loss? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sweating

 

The mechanism of heat loss in the given case is sweating.

 

As long as skin temperature is greater than the temperature of the surroundings, heat can be lost by radiation and conduction. But when the temperature of the surroundings becomes greater than that of the skin, instead of losing heat, the body gains heat by both radiation and conduction. Under these conditions, the only means by which the body can rid itself of heat is by evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation and B. Conduction are effective when the ambient temperature is lower than the body's skin temperature. However, at temperatures higher than the skin temperature, these methods can result in heat gain rather than heat loss.

 

Option C. Convection can aid in heat loss if the air movement can cool the skin, but at high environmental temperatures, its effectiveness is limited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high environmental temperatures, the body relies primarily on sweating and evaporation to lose heat and regulate body temperature effectively.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with septic shock. The physician decides to administer vasopressors to manage the patient's condition. The patient also requires multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access. A central venous catheter is inserted into the patient's internal jugular vein. Which of the following statements are true regarding central and peripheral venous access and their associated complications? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.
  2. Flushing with isotonic saline and heparin can maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.
  3. If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, peripheral venous access should be avoided in that same limb.
  4. Vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1 is true as phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.

 

Statement 2 is also true as flushing with isotonic saline and heparin is used to maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.

 

Statement 3 is true as the presence of an arteriovenous fistula in a limb is a relative contraindication for peripheral venous access in that same limb.

 

Statement 4 is also true as vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.

 

In this clinical case, the patient's septic shock required vasopressors, and multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access, leading to the insertion of a central venous catheter into the internal jugular vein. To prevent or avoid the formation of thrombus in venous catheters, the solutions used include 0.9% sodium chloride, heparin, vitamin C, and sodium citrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septic shock is a life-threatening medical condition that occurs as a result of a severe infection leading to a systemic inflammatory response. It is characterized by a combination of infection, low blood pressure (hypotension), and organ dysfunction. Here are some key points about septic shock:

 

  1. Infection: Septic shock typically begins with an infection, often caused by bacteria, but it can also result from fungal or viral infections. Common sources of infection include lung infections (pneumonia), urinary tract infections, abdominal infections, and skin infections.
  2. Systemic Inflammatory Response: In response to the infection, the body's immune system initiates a widespread inflammatory response. This response can become dysregulated, leading to an exaggerated release of inflammatory molecules (cytokines) into the bloodstream.
  3. Hypotension: One of the hallmark features of septic shock is low blood pressure (hypotension). The inflammation and vasodilation caused by the infection can lead to a drop in blood pressure, which can result in inadequate blood flow to vital organs.
  4. Organ Dysfunction: As blood pressure drops and organs receive less oxygen and nutrients, multiple organ systems can begin to fail. This can lead to dysfunction in the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, and other organs. Organ dysfunction is a critical component of septic shock and contributes to its high mortality rate.
  5. Symptoms: Symptoms of septic shock can include fever or hypothermia (low body temperature), rapid heart rate, rapid breathing, confusion, altered mental status, and signs of organ dysfunction such as respiratory distress, kidney failure, or liver dysfunction.
  6. Treatment: The treatment of septic shock is a medical emergency and involves aggressive interventions. It typically includes antibiotics to treat the underlying infection, intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure, vasopressor medications to constrict blood vessels and raise blood pressure, and supportive care in an intensive care unit (ICU).

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea
Christmas tree pattern - Lichen planus

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Option A.

 

Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

  • Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

Pityriasis Rosea:

 

  • This is a common skin condition characterized by a herald patch, followed by a distinctive, symmetric rash in a Christmas tree pattern.
  • It primarily affects the back and trunk. The rash is often accompanied by a Collarette scale, where the scale is more prominent at the periphery of the lesion.

 

Christmas Tree Pattern:

 

  • The symmetric distribution and orientation of lesions along the lines of skin cleavage on the back is a hallmark of pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Wickham’s Striae - Lichen Planus:

 

  • Wickham's striae are fine, white lines found on the surface of papules in lichen planus.
  • Surface of lichen planus lesions seen with oil on top of lesion reveals these whitish linear streaks.

 

 

  • Lichen planus typically presents with pruritic, purplish, polygonal papules and does not exhibit a Christmas tree pattern.

 

Option C. Christmas Tree Pattern - Lichen Planus:

 

This is incorrect because, although lichen planus is a common dermatologic condition, it does not present with a Christmas tree pattern. This pattern is specific to pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D. Woronoff Ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis:

 

  • The Woronoff ring is a hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions. It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical steroids.

 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy, scaly lesions predominantly on the scalp, face, and upper trunk.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with symmetrically distributed, asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on the back in a young adult, consider pityriasis rosea, particularly if the lesions follow a Christmas tree pattern.
  • This pattern, along with the presence of collarette scaling, is highly suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 35.8, 37.3, 115.9

questions.text: A patient after RTA (Road Traffic Accident) presented with hypovolemic shock. What is the reason for decreased cardiac output in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased preload

 

Hypovolemic shock, often caused by significant blood loss as in the case of a road traffic accident (RTA), leads to a decrease in the volume of blood returning to the heart (preload). Preload is the initial stretching of the cardiac myocytes prior to contraction, which is directly related to the volume of blood filling the heart. When there is a significant loss of blood volume, the preload decreases, leading to a reduced stroke volume and, consequently, decreased cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased afterload: This refers to the resistance the heart must overcome to eject blood. Increased afterload is not a primary issue in hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. High systemic vascular resistance: This would be more characteristic of distributive shock, such as septic shock, rather than hypovolemic shock.

 

Option D. Decreased contractility: While decreased contractility can reduce cardiac output, in hypovolemic shock, the primary problem is the loss of blood volume leading to decreased preload, not a primary issue with the heart muscle's ability to contract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypovolemic shock, the primary cause of decreased cardiac output is decreased preload due to significant loss of blood volume.

questions.text: The marked line corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. L3

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a diagram with a line indicating the subcostal plane, which corresponds to a specific vertebral level. The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark and is used to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical purposes.

 

  1. Subcostal Plane: The subcostal plane passes through the lowest point of the costal margin, which is generally at the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).
  2. Anatomical Landmarks:
    • The subcostal plane is a horizontal plane that typically lies just below the rib cage.
    • It is an important reference point for dividing the abdomen into regions.
    • The umbilicus, lies at the level of the L3-L4 junction, but the subcostal plane is typically slightly superior to this and corresponds to L3.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T12: This is incorrect. T12 is located higher up in the thoracic region.

 

Option B. L1: This is incorrect. The transpyloric plane, passes through the level of L1.

 

Option C. L2: This is incorrect. L2 is also superior to the subcostal plane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark that typically corresponds to the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3), helping to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical reference.

questions.text: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hereditary spherocytosis

 

Why Hereditary Spherocytosis is Correct: Hereditary spherocytosis is a condition characterized by the presence of spherical red blood cells that are prone to hemolysis. The spleen plays a significant role in the destruction of these abnormal red blood cells. Splenectomy is the treatment of choice for hereditary spherocytosis because it reduces hemolysis and anemia, leading to an improvement in the patient’s quality of life. It is typically recommended for patients with severe hemolysis or those who are transfusion-dependent.

 

  • Most Common Defect: The most common defect in hereditary spherocytosis is in the ankyrin protein.
  • Diagnostic Test: The investigation of choice for confirming hereditary spherocytosis is flow cytometry with eosin-5-maleimide. Historically, the osmotic fragility test was used.
  • Timing of Splenectomy: Splenectomy is generally performed after the age of 6 years and is indicated in patients with transfusion dependency anemia (majorly), severe anemia or growth retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G6PD deficiency: G6PD deficiency causes hemolysis primarily due to oxidative stress. Splenectomy is not beneficial because the spleen is not the primary site of red cell destruction in this condition.

 

Option B. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH involves intravascular hemolysis due to a defect in the red cell membrane. Splenectomy is not useful as the spleen is not involved in the hemolytic process.

 

Option D. Hairy cell leukemia: While splenectomy can sometimes be part of the management for symptomatic splenomegaly in hairy cell leukemia, it is not typically the first-line treatment. The primary treatment involves chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elective splenectomy is indicated in hereditary spherocytosis to decrease hemolysis and improve symptoms, particularly in patients with severe anemia or those who require frequent blood transfusions.

choices.text: Mullerian agenesis
Gonadal dysgenesis
Turner syndrome
Testicular feminization syndrome

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mullerian agenesis

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis.
  • Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • As ovaries are present, normal secondary sexual characters will develop

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis patients present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters poorly developed breasts

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters and short stature will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. The ovaries are streak ovaries

 

Option D. Testicular feminization syndrome: Testicular feminization syndrome also known as androgen insensitivity syndrome has a karyotype of 46XY. Secondary sexual characters like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

 

Educational Objective:


Mullerian agenesis is characterized by the absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, with normal ovarian function leading to normal breast and pubic hair development.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following refractory condition is depicted in the figure.  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Astigmatism

 

Astigmatism occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular shape, preventing light from focusing properly on the retina. This leads to blurred or distorted vision at all distances. Common symptoms include eyestrain, headaches, and difficulty seeing at night.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: This is a common condition associated with aging, where the eye's lens loses its ability to change shape to focus on close objects. Symptoms include difficulty reading small print or having to hold reading material farther away. Presbyopia typically starts to become noticeable in the early to mid-40s.

 

Option B. Myopia (Nearsightedness): This condition occurs when the eye is longer than normal or has a cornea that is too curved. As a result, light rays focus in front of the retina instead of on it. This leads to distant objects appearing blurry while close objects are seen clearly. Myopia is often identified in childhood or adolescence and can worsen during periods of rapid growth.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia (Farsightedness): In this condition, the eye is shorter than normal, or the cornea is not curved enough, causing light to focus behind the retina. This makes close objects appear blurry, while distant objects are usually seen clearly. Children often have some degree of hypermetropia, which can decrease as the eye grows and lengthens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing and understanding these refractive conditions is essential for early detection and management. Regular eye examinations are crucial, as they allow for the timely prescription of corrective lenses or other treatments. Each condition affects vision in a unique way, and understanding these differences is key in providing effective patient care and guidance.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

 

For a 60-year-old patient with diabetes and hypertension (BP 150/90 mmHg), it is critical to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Current guidelines, including the 2023 European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines, recommend initiating antihypertensive therapy in such patients due to the high risk of cardiovascular events. Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is an appropriate choice for initial antihypertensive therapy in diabetic patients. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is well-tolerated, without negatively impacting glycemic control. Ideally, an ACE inhibitor or ARB would be preferred, but if not available, a calcium channel blocker like amlodipine is a suitable alternative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Metoprolol: Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is not first-line therapy for hypertension unless there is a specific indication such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, or angina. Beta-blockers are not the preferred initial treatment for hypertensive diabetics.

 

Option B. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle modifications are important, they are insufficient alone for managing hypertension in a diabetic patient, who is at high cardiovascular risk.

 

Option C. Diet + Prazosin: Prazosin, an alpha-blocker, is not typically used as first-line therapy for hypertension. It may be used in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) but offers no additional advantage in this context and may cause orthostatic hypotension, worsening dizziness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive diabetic patients, it is essential to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Amlodipine is an appropriate choice for initial therapy in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles functions as a tensor of the vocal cords? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cricothyroid

 

Cricothyroid is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

The cricothyroid muscle is primarily responsible for lengthening and tensing the vocal cords. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the thyroid cartilage forward and down towards the cricoid cartilage, which results in elongation and tensioning of the vocal cords. This action increases the pitch of the voice. Because of its role in tensioning the vocal cords, the cricothyroid is sometimes referred to as a tensor of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscles are responsible for adducting the vocal cords. When these muscles contract, they rotate the arytenoid cartilages medially, which causes the vocal cords to come together. This action is crucial for phonation (production of sound), as the vocal cords must be close together to vibrate against each other. However, the lateral cricoarytenoids do not play a direct role in the tensioning or relaxation of the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoids: The thyroarytenoids are the primary muscles within the vocal cords themselves. They have two parts: the thyrovocalis (medial) and the thyromuscularis (lateral). The thyrovocalis is involved in the shortening and tensioning of the vocal cords, leading to a decrease in pitch. In contrast, the thyromuscularis aids in relaxing and thickening the cords, which lowers the pitch. Together, they play a critical role in controlling pitch and the quality of the voice.

 

Option D. Posterior cricoarytenoids: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the primary muscles responsible for abducting or opening the vocal cords. They rotate the arytenoid cartilages laterally, which pulls the vocal cords apart. This action is vital for breathing, as the vocal cords must be open for air to flow into the lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV
Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV
Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below? (AIIMS NOV 2021)

 

(RS cell: Reed - Sternberg cell, HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus, CMV: Cytomegalovirus, EBV: Epstein-Barr virus)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV

 

The probable diagnosis, cell, and virus from the given clinical scenario and the histopathological image are Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) respectively.

 

Identification of Reed-Sternberg cells and their variants is essential for the diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are large cells (≥45 μm in diameter) with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus about the size of a small lymphocyte (5–7 μm in diameter).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma does not typically feature Reed-Sternberg cells. While EBV can be associated with some types of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the presence of RS cells is specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option B. Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV: Kaposi sarcoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and often presents with spindle cells and slit-like vascular spaces, not Reed-Sternberg cells. It is more commonly associated with HIV.

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV: Infectious mononucleosis is usually associated with EBV, not CMV, and while it can cause atypical lymphocytosis, it does not produce Reed-Sternberg cells, which are specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin's lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, and it is often associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), particularly in specific subtypes.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of the device shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trophoblastic disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a copper-containing IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device).
  • ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device are:
    • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
    • Post abortal sepsis/ Puerperal sepsis/ Current Pelvic inflammatory/ disease, Genital Tuberculosis
    • Cancers: Endometrial cancer, Cervical cancer, Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
    • Large fibroid distorting the uterine cavity, Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Menstruation: Intra-uterine device can be inserted even during periods although preferably it should be inserted post-menstrual

 

Option C. Immediately after delivery: This is called as Post placental IUCD insertion (within 10 mins of placental delivery)

 

Option D. Ruptured condom during intercourse: Following a ruptured condom, CUT can be inserted as an emergency contraception

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophoblastic disease is an ABSOLUTE c/I to an Intra-uterine device.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241549158

questions.text: 65-year-old lady with a history of COPD and cor pulmonale presents with breathlessness and frequent exacerbations. Which of the following will improve survival in this patient?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long-term O2 therapy

 

For patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), there are only a few interventions proven to improve survival. These include smoking cessation, long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) for those who qualify, and lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) in selected patients. LTOT is particularly beneficial for patients with severe hypoxemia, as it helps maintain adequate oxygen levels, reducing the risk of heart failure and other complications associated with chronic hypoxemia.

 

In this case, the presence of cor pulmonale, which is a condition secondary to long-standing COPD leading to right heart failure, further strengthens the indication for LTOT. This therapy can help manage symptoms and prevent further deterioration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulization with budesonide: While this may help in managing symptoms of COPD by reducing inflammation and preventing exacerbations, it does not have a proven impact on improving overall survival.

 

Option C. Pneumococcal vaccine: This can reduce the risk of pneumococcal infections, which are common in COPD patients, but it does not directly improve survival in the long-term management of COPD.

 

Option D. Positive Pressure Ventilation:  This can be useful in managing acute exacerbations of COPD or chronic respiratory failure, but it is not typically used as a long-term therapy to improve survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) is one of the few interventions that improve survival in patients with COPD, especially those with severe hypoxemia and complications like cor pulmonale.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+

 

ER+ is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients as it is seen with luminal A and B subtypes of the breast cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Ki67+: High Ki67+ indicates a high proliferative index, which is associated with more aggressive tumors and a poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. BRCA1+: BRCA1 mutation is associated with an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers, and these cancers tend to be more aggressive.

 

Option D. P53+: P53 mutations are associated with a variety of cancers and typically indicate a poorer prognosis due to the loss of normal p53 tumor suppressor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

 

Why ER⁺ is a Good Prognostic Factor:

 

  1. Slower tumor growth:
    • ER⁺ tumors tend to grow more slowly than ER⁻ tumors.
  2. Better treatment response:
    • ER⁺ cancers respond well to hormonal therapies such as:
    • Tamoxifen
    • Aromatase inhibitors
  3. Lower recurrence risk:
    • Hormone receptor–positive cancers have a lower risk of early recurrence.
  4. Overall survival:
    • Patients with ER⁺ tumors generally have better overall survival.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

Patient presenting with a history of fever and cough for 5 days suggests diagnosis pneumonia. The chest X-ray showing opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.

 

Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.

 

 

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

 

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and something coming out of the vagina. Her last childbirth was 10 years back. On bimanual palpation, the uterus is palpable. On examination, the cervix admits 1 finger, and the following is seen. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroid polyp

 

The clinical presentation, including heavy menstrual bleeding, the presence of a vaginal mass, and the fact that the uterus is palpable on bimanual examination, strongly suggests a fibroid polyp. A fibroid polyp is a type of submucosal fibroid that protrudes into the uterine cavity and may extend through the cervix into the vagina. It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, including intermenstrual bleeding, due to the exposed surface of the polyp that can easily get eroded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenomyoma: This is incorrect. Adenomyoma, a localized form of adenomyosis, typically presents similarly to fibroids but does not cause a vaginal mass. The uterus would also be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open to admit a finger.

 

Option C. Intramural fibroid: This is incorrect. Intramural fibroids grow within the muscular wall of the uterus and do not typically protrude through the cervix to present as a vaginal mass. The uterus would be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open.

 

Option D. Inversion: This is incorrect. Uterine inversion usually occurs postpartum, often immediately after childbirth, or it can present as a chronic condition that began after a previous childbirth. In inversion, the uterus is typically not palpable on bimanual examination because it has turned inside out. The cervix would not admit a finger as the entire uterus is inside out, blocking access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fibroid polyp presents with heavy menstrual bleeding, a palpable uterus on bimanual examination, and a protruding mass in the vagina due to the fibroid extending through the cervix

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was started on amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). The patient was later found unconscious at home and brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient shows signs of arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation. Which of the following does NOT suggest TCA poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

Hypothermia is NOT typically associated with TCA poisoning. In fact, hyperthermia may occur due to anticholinergic effects leading to decreased sweating and heat dissipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning can lead to a variety of clinical manifestations, primarily due to their anticholinergic, sodium channel-blocking, and alpha-adrenergic blocking effects. The key features in this case would be:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias:

 

  • TCAs block sodium channels, leading to cardiac conduction delays, which can manifest as arrhythmias. They can also cause QT prolongation, predisposing to torsades de pointes.
  • Therefore, arrhythmias are a common and significant feature of TCA poisoning.

 

Option B. Confusion:

 

  • The anticholinergic effects of TCAs can lead to mental status changes, including confusion, agitation, and even delirium.
  • Confusion is a typical presentation in TCA overdose.

 

Option D. Pupillary Dilation:

 

  • Anticholinergic effects also include pupillary dilation (mydriasis) due to paralysis of the iris sphincter muscle.
  • Pupillary dilation is often observed in TCA toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia is not a typical feature of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning, whereas arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation are common clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are approved in all of the following except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rett Syndrome

 

Rett Syndrome: A rare genetic neurological disorder that primarily affects girls and leads to severe cognitive and physical impairments. While new treatments are being explored, cannabinoids are not currently approved for managing this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD) formulations such as Epidiolex, have been FDA-approved for use in treating certain epileptic syndromes. These include:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: A severe form of epilepsy that begins in infancy, characterized by prolonged seizures.

 

Option B. Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome: A childhood-onset epilepsy that involves multiple types of seizures and often results in cognitive impairment.

 

Option C. Tuberous Sclerosis: A genetic disorder that causes benign tumors to form in many parts of the body, including the brain, which can lead to seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannabinoids, such as Epidiolex, are approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, and Tuberous Sclerosis, but not for Rett Syndrome.

 

Note - High-dose Epidiolex is an FDA-approved oil formulation of CBD for use as an add-on treatment for Dravet's and Lennox-Gastaut syndromes and tuberous sclerosis epilepsies. There is clinical evidence for CBD, at lower doses, as an anxiolytic for the treatment of posttraumatic stress, anxiety, and relapse of substance use disorders. Animal studies suggest that this effect of CBD may be mediated by the 5-hydroxytryptamine 1A receptor.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is diagnosed with osteosarcoma and is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy as part of his treatment. Methotrexate is included in his chemotherapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of his osteosarcoma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR.

 

Methotrexate has different mechanisms for anticancer activity and for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

 

Mechanism in Osteosarcoma (As anticancer drug): Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate interferes with the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, an essential cofactor for DNA synthesis. This leads to a decrease in DNA and RNA synthesis, thereby arresting the cell cycle and inhibiting the growth of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells in osteosarcoma.

 

Mechanism in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): Methotrexate is used at much lower doses in Rheumatoid Arthritis. In this condition, the major mechanism involves the inhibition of an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, part of the purine synthesis pathway. When AICAR transformylase is inhibited, levels of AICAR (5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide ribonucleotide) accumulate in the cell. This leads to an inhibition of another enzyme called adenosine deaminase, which is responsible for the degradation of adenosine. As a result, adenosine levels increase within the cell and in the extracellular environment. Adenosine is known to have anti-inflammatory properties. When adenosine interacts with its receptors, it can lead to various effects such as inhibition of inflammatory cell function, vasodilation, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine release. These actions contribute to the anti-inflammatory effects observed when methotrexate is used for treating RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analog of UMP: Methotrexate is not an analog of UMP (uridine monophosphate). It does not exert its effects through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Blocks purine synthesis: Methotrexate does not specifically block purine synthesis, although the inhibition of DHFR indirectly affects purine and pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Blocks pyrimidine synthesis: Similar to Option C, methotrexate does not specifically block pyrimidine synthesis but indirectly affects it through DHFR inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate's primary mechanism of action in treating osteosarcoma is as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: On Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining oocysts of size 8-10 µm cysts are visible. Identify the organism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclospora

 

Cyclospora cayetanensis is a coccidian parasite that causes the gastrointestinal disease cyclosporiasis. The organism produces oocysts that are 8-10 µm in diameter, which can be detected by Ziehl-Neelsen staining. The oocysts exhibit a variable acid-fast staining property and can also autofluoresce under ultraviolet light.

 

Cyclospora oocysts have the following characteristics:

 

  • Size: 8-10 µm in diameter.
  • Staining: They show variable acid-fast staining.
  • Autofluorescence: They exhibit blue-green autofluorescence under ultraviolet light.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Isospora: Isospora (now known as Cystoisospora) produces larger oocysts, typically 20-30 µm in size, and contains two sporocysts with four sporozoites each. It does not match the 8-10 µm size described.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are smaller, measuring 4-6 µm in diameter, and consistently exhibit acid-fast staining and bright auramine fluorescence. They do not match the size range described.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are a group of spore-forming unicellular parasites that do not fit the description of having 8-10 µm oocysts visible with Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with colicky pain. Following type of crystals were found on urine examination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystinuria

 

The urine examination shows hexagonal crystals, which are characteristic of cystine crystals. These crystals are pathognomonic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder that affects the renal reabsorption of dibasic amino acids, including cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. Cystinuria leads to the formation of cystine stones in the kidneys, bladder, and ureters, often presenting with colicky pain due to stone obstruction.

 

Cystine crystals appear as flat, hexagonal plates, which is a distinctive feature that helps differentiate them from other types of crystals seen in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ADPKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): This condition involves the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney enlargement and dysfunction. It does not typically present with hexagonal crystals in the urine; the crystals seen are more commonly calcium oxalate.

 

Option B. Calcium oxalate stones: These stones are among the most common kidney stones and appear as envelope or dumbbell-shaped crystals, not hexagonal. They are usually related to hyperoxaluria and not cystinuria.

 

Option D. Glomerulonephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys, leading to symptoms like hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension. It does not present with specific crystals like the hexagonal cystine crystals seen in cystinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hexagonal cystine crystals in urine are characteristic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder affecting the renal absorption of certain amino acids, leading to recurrent cystine stone formation.

questions.text: Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

Correct matches

 

 

PUVA (Psoralen and Ultraviolet A)

 

  • Over 90% of cases of psoriasis are successfully treated with PUVA.
  • Both acute (erythema, blistering) and chronic side effects are associated with it.
  • Use of PUVA for an extended period is linked to non-melanoma skin cancer development (squamous cell and basal cell cancers).

 

Cyclosporine

 

  • Cyclosporine usage is primarily linked to metabolic issues, a possible increased risk of malignancy, and renal impairment (decreased GFR).
  • Due to its nephrotoxic effects, it is now uncommonly used for the maintenance of psoriasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common therapies for psoriasis with their potential side effects:

 

  • PUVA increases the risk of skin cancer (1-c),
  • Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic (2-b),
  • Methotrexate can act as an abortifacient (3-a), and
  • Acitretin is teratogenic and can cause mucositis (4-d).

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.26-28

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 3402

choices.text: Supposititious child

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins belonging to two different fathers. This case would be best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfecundation

 

  • Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus 
    • So twin pregnancy in both
    • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both Superfecundation and superfetation
  • Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
    • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time, whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

 

In the question, it is mentioned that “woman gave birth to twins”, which implies that both babies were born at same time. Hence superfecundation is a better choice than superfetation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: Fertilization of a second ovum during a different menstrual cycle while a pregnancy is already ongoing. The first fetus is more developed than the second, and they may not be born at the same time.

 

Option C. Supposititious children are fraudulent offspring. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine.

 

Option D. Atavism: A modification of a biological structure whereby an ancestral genetic trait reappears after having been lost through evolutionary change in previous generations. E.g. tail in humans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two ova from separate acts of coitus within the same menstrual cycle, resulting in the birth of twins that can have different fathers and are born at the same time.

questions.text: A patient came following an RTA in the hospital. He is able to understand his friend’s talks. He is trying to speak (non-fluent aphasia) something to his friend. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Broca’s area

 

Explanation:

 

Broca’s area is responsible for speech production and language processing. It is located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere) of the brain. Injury to Broca’s area leads to Broca’s aphasia, also known as non-fluent aphasia. Individuals with this condition can understand spoken language but have difficulty in speaking, writing, or forming words properly.

 

Broca’s area: Broca’s aphasia is characterized by difficulty in speech production. The patient may understand speech but will struggle to speak fluently, often speaking in short, broken sentences with considerable effort. This condition is also known as expressive aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke’s area: This area is involved in the comprehension of spoken language. Damage to Wernicke’s area results in Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent aphasia), where the patient can speak fluently but the speech is often nonsensical and lacks meaning.

 

Option B. Angular gyrus: This region is involved in various functions related to language, number processing, and spatial cognition but is not directly responsible for speech production or comprehension.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: This is a bundle of nerve fibers that connects Broca’s area and Wernicke’s area. Damage to this pathway can result in conduction aphasia, characterized by the ability to understand and produce speech but difficulty in repeating words or sentences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca’s area is involved in speech production. Damage to this area results in non-fluent (expressive) aphasia, where the patient can understand speech but has difficulty speaking fluently.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, ovarian drilling is beneficial? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used in management of polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Management of PCOS typically starts lifestyle modification.  Medical management with metformin (for insulin resistance) and then depending on the symptoms that a patient presents with such as irregular menses (OC pills, Progesterone), hirsuitism (cyproterone acetate, Spironolactone) or infertility (Oral Ovulogens such as letrozole, clomiphene) may be considered.

 

Ovarian drilling is NOT a first-line treatment and may be considered in resistant cases.

 

LAPAROSCOPIC OVARIAN DRILLING

 

  • Small holes are made in follicles to resume ovulation in women who are not responding to drugs.
  • Advantage: induce the resumption of ovulation in more than 50% females
  • Disadvantages: invasive procedure, can cause adhesion.
  • 4 drills should be done in each ovary. Depth of 4mm for 4 seconds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian tumour: Treatment would generally involve laparotomy or laparoscopy  for surgical excision depending on various factors such as whether benign or malignant, size of tumour , staging etc

 

Option C. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome:  It occurs as a complication of ovarian stimulation used in ART procedures characterized by enlarged ovaries and third space fluid loss due to increased capillary permeability progressing to ascites, pleural effusion. It is managed conservatively.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: It is characterized by the presence of ectopic endometrium in locations other than the endometrial lining. Treatment may be conservative medical management or surgical excision of the endometriotic lesions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is used in management of polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynaecology page471

questions.text: Identify the brain malformation shown in the given MRI image. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arnold Chiari malformation

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is a condition where there is herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This malformation is characterized by downward displacement of the cerebellum, particularly the tonsils, which can be observed on MRI scans as a distinctive pattern of herniation below the level of the foramen magnum. The provided radiograph shows this exact presentation, with cerebellar tissue extending through the foramen magnum, indicating Arnold Chiari malformation.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus callosal agenesis: This condition involves the complete or partial absence of the corpus callosum, the structure that connects the two cerebral hemispheres. This malformation would not present with cerebellar herniation on imaging but would show an absence of the corpus callosum on MRI.

 

Option B. Vein of Galen malformation: This is a vascular malformation involving an abnormal connection between cerebral arteries and veins. It would appear as a large, dilated venous structure on imaging and would not show herniation of the cerebellum.

 

Option C. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition is characterized by cystic enlargement of the fourth ventricle, partial or complete absence of the cerebellar vermis, and enlargement of the posterior fossa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arnold Chiari malformation is identified by the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, visible on MRI scans as the downward displacement of cerebellar tissue.
